repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
@lewis6991 

Add memory to avoid repetitive string comparisons

Why is this important?

take for example these files in 3 way diff mode with linematch enabled:
file 1:
1a
1b
1c

file 2:
2a
2b
2c

file 3:
3a
3b
3c

there are repetitive calls to matching_chars which are unecessary, and the amount of these calls increases rapidly with larger diffs with over 3 buffers open in diff mode.

with:
27 calls to `matching_chars`
without:
189 calls to `matching_chars`

add a single extra line to each file for 4 lines each:
with:
48 calls to `matching_chars`
without:
432 calls to `matching_chars`

comment_regular_data.body:
Allocs are really expensive. Is it possible to either allocate on the stack or reduce the amount of allocs by allocating larger blocks up front?

Otherwise we will probably need to benchmark to make sure this is worth it.

I timed linematch_nbuffers using:

  ```
  clock_t begin = clock();
  ...
  clock_t end = clock();
  double time_spent = 1000 * (double)(end - begin) / CLOCKS_PER_SEC; // ms
  ```

3 files diff, each file with 50, then 100 lines, time (ms)

```
100 line_no_optimization:   12060.486000
100 line_with_optimization: 8807.395000

50 line_no_optimization:    1056.282000
50 line_with_optimization:  604.096000

25 line_no_optimization:    94.120000
25 line_with_optimization:  50.467000
```

it almost halves the time

my complexity analysis:

  this additional memory for comparisons is always O(n2)

  the grid that is already used for linematch is more expensive once you exceed 4 buffers (in terms of total space allocated)

    2 buffers: O(n)
    3 buffers: O(n2)
    4 buffers: O(n3)


anyway, I may be able to reduce the amount of xmalloc calls and index it with
unwrap_indexes.

What do you think?
![Spacecomplexity](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/32371757/234124876-0ccb921b-5656-4b7a-9eae-8c94aa7a8f60.png)

Sounds good!

Looks like all the extra allocs are definitely hurting.

We know all the space upfront so we should be able to minimise this right down.

Okay. 
Do you know how to get a time profile showing what percentage of time each of the functions is taking up?

I was trying to get gprof to work and was not successful. I think it needs the -gp flag passed to gcc somehow
Updated, There is now a constant total of 3 xmallocs introduced by this change

Wow, very good.

Did you find out if this improved perf further?

I'm quite surprised by that. Maybe the fact the fewer allocs forces the memory to be more contiguous and thus makes it harder to allocate.

Either way, there's a clear improvement doing this, so I'll let you decide what's best.
I vote for the original one because it's less lines added and probably more readable with the lack of index unwrapping
Need rebase and please think about any potential cleanup/simpflication.

labels.description: Waiting for reply, will auto-close after 30 days.
labels.name: needs:response

title: fix(diff): remove repetitive comparisons between strings with linematch
